segments.en: Hello, everyone, and welcome back to EnglishPod.
My name is Marco.
And I'm Erica.
And today with Erica we have an upper intermediate lesson.
segments.cn: 今天和Erica一起，我们有一节中高级课程。

segments.en: That's right, an upper intermediate lesson that's a little bit strange.
segments.cn: 没错，这是一节有点奇怪的中高级课程。

segments.en: It's a little bit strange, but it's a real English lesson because that's what we give you here at EnglishPod.
segments.cn: 这有点奇怪，但这是真正的英语课程，因为这就是我们在EnglishPod提供的。

segments.en: So in today's lesson we've got a lot of really great language for you.
segments.cn: 所以在今天的课程中，我们有很多很棒的语言要分享给你。

segments.en: We've got language to help you to gossip better.
segments.cn: 我们有帮助你更好地八卦的语言。

segments.en: Gossip.
Why don't you explain it a little bit just in case.
segments.cn: 你能稍微解释一下吗，以防万一。

segments.en: Okay, so if I gossip I maybe share news or information about other people with my friends.
segments.cn: 好的，如果我八卦，我可能会和我的朋友分享关于其他人的新闻或信息。

segments.en: Like I might say something like, Marco, did you see what happened in ChinesePod today?
segments.cn: 比如我可能会说，Marco，你看到今天在ChinesePod发生了什么吗？

segments.en: You'll never guess what I saw.
segments.cn: 你绝对猜不到我看到的。

segments.en: Exactly, that's gossip.
And we also have language today to describe things.
segments.cn: 我们今天还有描述事物的语言。

segments.en: To describe strange things.
Strange things.
Alright, so let's take a look at our vocabulary preview.
segments.cn: 好的，让我们看看我们的词汇预览。

segments.en: Vocabulary preview.
So in our vocabulary preview we'll look at a few important words that will help you to understand the dialogue a little bit better.
segments.cn: 在我们的词汇预览中，我们将查看一些重要的单词，帮助你更好地理解对话。

segments.en: Exactly, and the first word is weird.
segments.cn: 没错，第一个单词是奇怪。

segments.en: Weird.
Weird.
Weird.
Now this is a common word you probably hear all the time and in a lot of different situations, so we wanted to explain it today.
segments.cn: 这是一个常见的单词，你可能在很多不同的场合听到，所以我们今天想解释一下。

segments.en: Yeah, this word just means strange.
segments.cn: 是的，这个词的意思就是奇怪。

segments.en: It's strange.
Yeah.
Weird person is a strange person.
segments.cn: 奇怪的人就是一个奇怪的人。

segments.en: Exactly, but the thing about this word is if you are a young person, let's say under the age of 35, you'll probably use it about a hundred times a day.
segments.cn: 没错，但这个词的特点是，如果你是年轻人，比如说35岁以下，你可能每天会用到大约一百次。

segments.en: Weird.
Yeah.
It's just such a good sounding word.
Weird.
It is.
Okay, but the thing is that even though it is probably more commonly used in American English, it's still widely used for British English as well.
segments.cn: 好的，但问题是，尽管它在美式英语中可能更常用，但在英式英语中也广泛使用。

segments.en: Yeah, that's true.
So, but maybe in British English you would say something like... Odd.
segments.cn: 所以，在英式英语中你可能会说... 奇怪。

segments.en: It's odd.
Yeah.
That's more common.
Okay, let's look at our second word.
segments.cn: 好的，让我们看看第二个单词。

segments.en: Housewarming gift.
Housewarming gift.
Housewarming gift.
Housewarming gift.
Now this is a cultural thing.
It's really common in North America to give a housewarming gift to someone.
segments.cn: 在北美，给人送乔迁礼物是很常见的。

segments.en: Yeah, if I move into a new house, maybe some of my friends or family will bring a gift over to make my house a little bit more beautiful.
segments.cn: 是的，如果我搬进新家，也许我的一些朋友或家人会带礼物来，让我的家更美丽。

segments.en: So something like a photo frame or... or maybe a plant or sometimes even like maybe a basket of pastries or something.
segments.cn: 比如一个相框，或者... 或者也许是一盆植物，或者有时甚至是一篮糕点之类的东西。

segments.en: Okay.
Yeah.
I've never gotten one of those because I don't have a home.
segments.cn: 我从来没有收到过这些，因为我没有家。

segments.en: Where do you live?
On the street?
Well, I don't have my own home, so I have never gotten one of those.
segments.cn: 嗯，我没有自己的家，所以我从来没有收到过这些。

segments.en: Okay.
Okay, so we're ready now to listen to our dialogue.
segments.cn: 好的，现在我们准备好听我们的对话了。

segments.en: So we've got two housewives who are gossiping about what's going on in the neighborhood and let's listen to what happens.
segments.cn: 我们有两个家庭主妇在八卦邻里的事情，让我们听听发生了什么。

segments.en: Oh, I don't know if you've heard but someone moved into that old house down the road.
segments.cn: 哦，我不知道你听说过没有，但有人搬进了那条路上的旧房子。

segments.en: Yeah, I know.
I met the owner of the house yesterday as he was moving in.
segments.cn: 昨天我遇到了房子的主人，他正在搬进来。

segments.en: His name is Armand.
Really?
What's he like?
You have to fill me in.
Actually, he's a bit strange.
I don't know.
I've just got a bad feeling about him.
segments.cn: 我对他有种不好的感觉。

segments.en: Really?
Why?
Well, yesterday I brought over a housewarming gift but Armand started acting really weird and then he practically kicked me out.
segments.cn: 嗯，昨天我带了一份乔迁礼物过来，但Armand开始表现得很奇怪，然后几乎把我赶走了。

segments.en: I tried to sort of peek into his house but everything was so dark inside that I couldn't really get a good look.
segments.cn: 我试着偷偷看他的房子，但里面太黑了，我根本看不清楚。

segments.en: The whole thing really creeped me out.
segments.cn: 整个事情让我感到很毛骨悚然。

segments.en: Well, you'll never guess what I saw this morning.
segments.cn: 嗯，你绝对猜不到我今天早上看到的。

segments.en: A delivery truck pulled into his driveway and it dropped off a long rectangular box.
segments.cn: 一辆送货车开进了他的车道，放下了一个长方形的盒子。

segments.en: It almost looked like a coffin.
segments.cn: 它看起来几乎像一个棺材。

segments.en: You see?
Why would he...?
Hello, ladies.
Armand!
You scared the heck out of me.
This is my friend Doris.
Pleasure to meet you.
If you're not doing anything tonight, I'd like to have you both for dinner.
segments.cn: 如果你们今晚没事，我想请你们吃晚餐。

segments.en: I mean, I'd like to have you both over for dinner.
segments.cn: 我是说，我想请你们来吃晚餐。

segments.en: Ooh, that guy seems kind of weird.
segments.cn: 哦，那家伙看起来有点奇怪。

segments.en: You can hear his voice is like a weird guy, right?
segments.cn: 你听他的声音就像个奇怪的人，对吧？

segments.en: Yeah.
All right, let's take a look at our language takeaway and look at some of these great words.
segments.cn: 好的，让我们看看我们的语言要点，看看这些很棒的单词。

segments.en: Language takeaway.
So, our language takeaway focuses on several words from the dialogue that we feel are really important for you to know.
segments.cn: 我们的语言要点关注对话中的几个单词，我们认为这些单词对你来说非常重要。

segments.en: Exactly, and we have four of them for you today.
segments.cn: 没错，今天我们有四个单词给你。

segments.en: Why don't we look at the first one?
Okay, so the first word is a bad feeling.
segments.cn: 好的，第一个词是不好的感觉。

segments.en: Bad feeling.
A bad feeling.
A bad feeling.
So, we've got a few examples that will help you to understand how this phrase works.
segments.cn: 所以，我们有一些例子可以帮助你理解这个短语是如何运作的。

segments.en: Example one.
I don't like Kelly's new boyfriend.
segments.cn: 我不喜欢凯莉的新男朋友。

segments.en: I've got a bad feeling about him.
segments.cn: 我对他有种不好的感觉。

segments.en: Example two.
It's so dark.
We shouldn't be out here.
I've got a bad feeling about this.
segments.cn: 我对这件事有种不好的感觉。

segments.en: Example three.
I've got a bad feeling about this trip.
segments.cn: 我对这次旅行有种不好的感觉。

segments.en: I feel like something's going to happen.
Maybe we shouldn't go.
Okay, so basically you think something bad is gonna happen.
segments.cn: 好吧，所以基本上你觉得会发生坏事。

segments.en: Yeah, you have a sort of uncomfortable feeling.
segments.cn: 是的，你有种不舒服的感觉。

segments.en: Okay, that makes sense.
Have a bad feeling about something.
Exactly.
Okay, let's look at our second word now.
segments.cn: 好吧，现在我们来看第二个词。

segments.en: Kicked me out.
Kicked me out.
Kicked me out.
Kicked me out.
So when someone kicks you out, it's they force you to leave.
segments.cn: 所以当有人把你踢出去时，就是他们强迫你离开。

segments.en: You don't want to leave, but they force you to leave.
segments.cn: 你不想离开，但他们强迫你离开。

segments.en: Yeah.
Marco, have you ever kicked someone out of your class?
segments.cn: 马尔科，你有没有把某人踢出你的课堂？

segments.en: Yes, I have.
Really?
Yeah, if you misbehave in my class, you're kicked out.
segments.cn: 是的，如果你在我的课堂上表现不当，就会被踢出去。

segments.en: So you're pretty strict, huh?
Sometimes I am.
Okay, also maybe you've kicked your husband out of bed.
segments.cn: 好吧，也许你把你丈夫踢出了床。

segments.en: I might have done that once or twice before.
segments.cn: 我可能之前做过一两次。

segments.en: We'll have to ask him.
I'm sure he has.
Alright, so that's what it means.
You force someone to leave the house, leave the class, leave the bed.
segments.cn: 你强迫某人离开房子、离开课堂、离开床。

segments.en: So kicked out of class, kicked out of the house, kicked out of bed.
segments.cn: 所以被踢出课堂、被踢出房子、被踢出床。

segments.en: Exactly.
Great.
Let's look at our third word now.
segments.cn: 现在我们来看第三个词。

segments.en: Creeped me out.
Creeped me out.
Creeped me out.
Creeped me out.
Now this is a really common phrase.
segments.cn: 这是一个非常常见的短语。

segments.en: I like this phrase a lot, and we've got some examples for you to listen to, to help you understand this word a little bit better.
segments.cn: 我非常喜欢这个短语，我们有一些例子供你听，以帮助你更好地理解这个词。

segments.en: Example one.
Shh.
Did you hear that?
Oh, I think I saw something.
Stop it.
You're really creeping me out.
segments.cn: 你真的让我感到毛骨悚然。

segments.en: Example two.
This place really creeps me out.
segments.cn: 这个地方真的让我感到毛骨悚然。

segments.en: Let's get out of here.
Alright, well I have a confession to make.
I'm kind of creeped out by clowns.
You are?
Yes, I don't know.
They're just creepy.
segments.cn: 他们就是让人毛骨悚然。

segments.en: They scare me.
Really?
What is it about clowns that scare you so much?
segments.cn: 小丑有什么让你这么害怕的？

segments.en: I don't know.
They're just white faces and weird paint.
segments.cn: 他们就是白色的脸和奇怪的妆。

segments.en: I don't know.
It's just creepy.
The way they laugh.
I don't know.
Maybe you had a bad experience with clowns as a child.
segments.cn: 也许你小时候和小丑有过不好的经历。

segments.en: Probably.
I watched the scary movie about clowns or something.
segments.cn: 我看过关于小丑的恐怖电影。

segments.en: Alright.
So creeped me out basically means made me feel uncomfortable.
segments.cn: 所以“让我感到毛骨悚然”基本上意味着让我感到不舒服。

segments.en: Yes, it scares you.
Yeah.
Well, speaking of being scared, we have our final word for a language takeaway, and it is scared the heck out of me.
segments.cn: 好吧，谈到害怕，我们有最后一个词作为语言收获，那就是“吓得我半死”。

segments.en: You scared the heck out of me.
Scared the heck out of me.
You got really scared.
Yeah.
I think this is a quite common way of saying you really, really scared me.
segments.cn: 我觉得这是一种很常见的说法，表示你真的、真的吓到我了。

segments.en: Yeah.
Okay.
We're ready to listen to our dialogue again.
segments.cn: 我们准备好再听一次对话。

segments.en: Now try and see if you can catch all these phrases that we just talked about.
segments.cn: 现在试着看看你能否捕捉到我们刚刚谈到的所有短语。

segments.en: Oh, I don't know if you've heard, but someone moved into that old house down the road.
segments.cn: 哦，我不知道你是否听说过，但有人搬进了那条路上的老房子。

segments.en: Yeah, I know.
I met the owner of the house yesterday as he was moving in.
segments.cn: 昨天我遇到了房子的主人，他正在搬进来。

segments.en: His name is Armand.
Really?
What's he like?
You have to fill me in.
Actually, he's a bit strange.
I don't know.
I've just got a bad feeling about him.
segments.cn: 我对他有种不好的感觉。

segments.en: Really?
Why?
Well, yesterday I brought over a housewarming gift, but Armand started acting really weird, and then he practically kicked me out.
segments.cn: 嗯，昨天我带了一份乔迁礼物，但阿尔芒开始表现得很奇怪，然后他几乎把我踢了出去。

segments.en: I tried to sort of peek into his house, but everything was so dark inside that I couldn't really get a good look.
segments.cn: 我试着窥视他的房子，但里面太黑了，我根本看不清楚。

segments.en: The whole thing really creeped me out.
segments.cn: 整个事情真的让我感到毛骨悚然。

segments.en: Well, you'll never guess what I saw this morning.
segments.cn: 嗯，你绝对猜不到我今天早上看到的。

segments.en: A delivery truck pulled into his driveway and it dropped off a long rectangular box.
segments.cn: 一辆送货车开进了他的车道，放下了一个长方形的盒子。

segments.en: It almost looked like a coffin.
segments.cn: 它看起来几乎像个棺材。

segments.en: You see?
Why would he... Hello, ladies.
segments.cn: 他为什么会…… 你好，女士们。

segments.en: Ah, Armand!
You scared the heck out of me.
This is my friend, Doris.
A pleasure to meet you.
If you are not doing anything tonight, I would like to have you both for dinner.
segments.cn: 如果你今晚没事，我想请你们俩吃晚饭。

segments.en: I mean, I would like to have you both over for dinner.
segments.cn: 我是说，我想请你们俩来吃晚饭。

segments.en: You know, one of the things I really like about this dialogue is there's a lot of great phrases that will help you to gossip.
segments.cn: 你知道，我真的很喜欢这个对话中的一些短语，它们会帮助你八卦。

segments.en: That's a good observation, so I think it's time for Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 这是个好观察，所以我觉得是时候进行流利表达训练了。

segments.en: Fluency Builder In Fluency Builder, we take a simple phrase or a simple word you already know and show you how to express the same idea a little bit more naturally.
segments.cn: 流利表达训练 在流利表达训练中，我们会拿一个你已经知道的简单短语或单词，教你如何更自然地表达同样的意思。

segments.en: Okay, great.
So let's take a look at our first item for Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 那我们来看看流利表达训练的第一个项目。

segments.en: So when you gossip with somebody, you often tell them news or information that they don't know already.
segments.cn: 当你和某人八卦时，你通常会告诉他们一些他们不知道的新闻或信息。

segments.en: And you might start by saying, Did you know that?
segments.cn: 你可以开始说， 你知道吗？

segments.en: Or you can say, Did you hear?
segments.cn: 或者你可以说， 你听说了吗？

segments.en: Yeah, both of those phrases are perfectly fine.
segments.cn: 是的，这两个短语都很好。

segments.en: But if you want to sound a little bit more native-like when you're gossiping, you might try out this phrase from the dialogue.
segments.cn: 但如果你想在八卦时听起来更像本地人，你可以试试对话中的这个短语。

segments.en: I don't know if you've heard.
segments.cn: 我不知道你是否听说过。

segments.en: I don't know if you've heard.
segments.cn: 我不知道你是否听说过。

segments.en: Yeah, that's a really good phrase.
segments.cn: 是的，这是个很好的短语。

segments.en: You're saying exactly the same thing, but in a really natural way.
segments.cn: 你说的完全一样，但方式更自然。

segments.en: It's a great one for gossiping.
segments.cn: 这是个很好的八卦短语。

segments.en: So Marco, I don't know if you've heard, but Chinese Pod is up to some pretty crazy things.
segments.cn: 所以马尔科，我不知道你是否听说过，但中文播客正在做一些非常疯狂的事情。

segments.en: See, that's exactly how you would use that phrase.
segments.cn: 看，这正是你使用那个短语的方式。

segments.en: So now let's take a look at our second item.
segments.cn: 现在我们来看看第二个项目。

segments.en: Now, when you're gossiping, you want information.
segments.cn: 当你在八卦时，你想要信息。

segments.en: That's right.
So you might say, Oh, tell me about it.
segments.cn: 所以你可能会说， 哦，告诉我吧。

segments.en: Or something like, Give me the details.
Yeah, and again, both of these examples are perfectly fine.
segments.cn: 是的，这两个例子都很好。

segments.en: But when you're gossiping, you might want to try something like this.
segments.cn: 但当你在八卦时，你可能想试试这样的说法。

segments.en: You have to fill me in.
You have to fill me in.
Fill me in.
Yeah, that's that's what I would say.
Fill me in.
You know, give me the details.
Fill me in.
Fill me in on today's gossip.
Okay, so let's take a look at our third item.
segments.cn: 好的，那我们来看看第三个项目。

segments.en: Now, if you have some juicy gossipy news.
segments.cn: 现在，如果你有一些劲爆的八卦新闻。

segments.en: And you want to start up a conversation, you might use this phrase here.
segments.cn: 而你想开始一个对话，你可以使用这个短语。

segments.en: Well, you'll never guess what I saw this morning.
segments.cn: 嗯，你绝对猜不到我今天早上看到的。

segments.en: Well, you'll never guess what I saw this morning.
segments.cn: 嗯，你绝对猜不到我今天早上看到的。

segments.en: That's a really good phrase.
You can change it a little bit.
You can say, You'll never guess who I saw.

segments.en: Or you'll never guess what I heard.
segments.cn: 或者你绝对猜不到我听到了什么。

segments.en: Exactly.
Very excellent gossip phrases.
We're teaching you how to gossip because that's real English.

segments.en: People really do it.
So you got to know the language for it.

segments.en: I mean, I'd like to have you both over for dinner.
segments.cn: 我是说，我想请你们俩来吃晚饭。

segments.en: Okay, Marco, I have a true story for you.
segments.cn: 好吧，马尔科，我有一个真实的故事要告诉你。

segments.en: Is it kind of like a creepy story?
segments.cn: 是那种令人毛骨悚然的故事吗？

segments.en: It is a creepy story indeed.
segments.cn: 确实是个令人毛骨悚然的故事。

segments.en: Is it a true story?
No, it's really true.
So when I was young, I used to live in the country.
segments.cn: 所以当我年轻的时候，我曾住在乡下。

segments.en: And you know, in the country, all of the neighbors know each other.
segments.cn: 你知道，在乡下，所有邻居都彼此认识。

segments.en: It's a small community, so everyone knows what's happening all the time.
segments.cn: 这是个小社区，所以每个人都知道发生了什么。

segments.en: Okay.
And there was some gossip going on in our community about a guy who lived at the end of the road.
segments.cn: 我们社区里有关于一个住在路尽头的家伙的八卦。

segments.en: And he was the owner of a car wrecking yard.
segments.cn: 他是一个汽车拆解场的老板。

segments.en: So a place where you take old broken down cars and take the parts apart to sell.
segments.cn: 就是一个把旧车拆解零件出售的地方。

segments.en: And anyway... A scrap yard.
Yeah, a scrap yard.
All right.
Okay, so, you know, he had a wife and a couple of kids.
segments.cn: 好吧，你知道，他有一个妻子和几个孩子。

segments.en: And suddenly his wife disappeared.
segments.cn: 然后他的妻子突然消失了。

segments.en: Wow.
Yeah.
And no one knew what happened or anything.
segments.cn: 没有人知道发生了什么。

segments.en: And so several years passed.
And suddenly the police start coming in and start investigating this guy and start digging up all of the land around his property.
segments.cn: 突然，警察开始来调查这个家伙，挖掘他财产周围的土地。

segments.en: And I guess, I don't know what they're doing, but I think they were looking for the wife's body.
segments.cn: 我想，我不知道他们在做什么，但我觉得他们是在寻找妻子的尸体。

segments.en: Wow.
And did they find it?
I don't know.
I moved away.
Oh, such a great story, but we don't know how it ends.
segments.cn: 哦，真是个好故事，但我们不知道结局。

segments.en: Well, we can leave it up to the imagination of our listeners.
segments.cn: 好吧，我们可以留给听众的想象。

segments.en: Exactly.
Maybe they were looking for an old car.
segments.cn: 也许他们在寻找一辆旧车。

segments.en: An old car buried in the ground?
I don't think so.
All right.
That's a true story.
Real English, real stories.
segments.cn: 真实的英语，真实的故事。

segments.en: You heard it first here on EnglishPod.
All right.
So we want to hear your comments and suggestions about this topic.
segments.cn: 所以我们想听听你们对这个话题的评论和建议。

segments.en: I bet a lot of our listeners also have creepy stories, maybe ghost stories, maybe, I don't know, different types of weird stories.
segments.cn: 我敢打赌，我们的许多听众也有诡异的故事，也许是鬼故事，或者，我不知道，各种奇怪的故事。

segments.en: So you guys should definitely log on to EnglishPod and share them with us.
segments.cn: 所以你们一定要登录EnglishPod，和我们分享。

segments.en: That's right.
Go to EnglishPod.com and in the comments section of the website, tell us your creepy stories.
segments.cn: 访问EnglishPod.com，在网站的评论区告诉我们你的诡异故事。

segments.en: And we're going to pick out the best story as the story of the week.
segments.cn: 我们将选出最好的故事作为本周故事。

segments.en: We'll announce it in our This Just In podcast.
segments.cn: 我们将在我们的《最新消息》播客中宣布。

segments.en: Yes.
So we want to hear all your juicy stories and gossip maybe as well.
segments.cn: 所以我们想听听你们所有的精彩故事和八卦。

segments.en: Yes.
All right.
Well, it's time for us to go, so be sure to listen to us next time.
segments.cn: 好吧，是时候走了，所以下次一定要听我们。

segments.en: But until then, it's... Bye -bye.
Bye.
